# _Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides_

_**Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides**_ is a 2011 American
[fantasy](/wiki/Fantasy_film "Fantasy film") [swashbuckler
film](/wiki/Swashbuckler_film "Swashbuckler film"), the fourth installment in
the [_Pirates of the Caribbean_ film
series](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean_\(film_series\) "Pirates of the
Caribbean \(film series\)") and the sequel to _[At World's
End](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_At_World%27s_End "Pirates of the
Caribbean: At World's End")_ (2007). It is the first film in the series not to
be directed by [Gore Verbinski](/wiki/Gore_Verbinski "Gore Verbinski"), being
replaced by [Rob Marshall](/wiki/Rob_Marshall "Rob Marshall"). [Jerry
Bruckheimer](/wiki/Jerry_Bruckheimer "Jerry Bruckheimer") again served as
producer. The film is technically a [stand-alone
sequel](/wiki/Sequel#Standalone_sequels "Sequel") to the previous
installments. In the film, which draws its plot loosely from the novel _[On
Stranger Tides](/wiki/On_Stranger_Tides "On Stranger Tides")_ by [Tim
Powers](/wiki/Tim_Powers "Tim Powers"), [Captain Jack
Sparrow](/wiki/Jack_Sparrow "Jack Sparrow") ([Johnny Depp](/wiki/Johnny_Depp
"Johnny Depp")) is joined by
[Angelica](/wiki/Angelica_\(Pirates_of_the_Caribbean\) "Angelica \(Pirates of
the Caribbean\)") ([Penélope Cruz](/wiki/Pen%C3%A9lope_Cruz "Penélope Cruz"))
in his search for the [Fountain of Youth](/wiki/Fountain_of_Youth "Fountain of
Youth"), confronting the infamous pirate
[Blackbeard](/wiki/Blackbeard_\(Pirates_of_the_Caribbean\) "Blackbeard
\(Pirates of the Caribbean\)") ([Ian McShane](/wiki/Ian_McShane "Ian
McShane")). The film was produced by [Walt Disney
Pictures](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures "Walt Disney Pictures") and released in
the United States on May 20, 2011. It was the first film in the series to be
released in the [Disney Digital 3-D](/wiki/Disney_Digital_3-D "Disney Digital
3-D") and [IMAX 3D](/wiki/IMAX_3D "IMAX 3D") formats.

Writers [Ted Elliott](/wiki/Ted_Elliott_\(screenwriter\) "Ted Elliott
\(screenwriter\)") and [Terry Rossio](/wiki/Terry_Rossio "Terry Rossio") first
learned of Powers' novel _[On Stranger Tides](/wiki/On_Stranger_Tides "On
Stranger Tides")_ during the back-to-back production of _[Dead Man's
Chest](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_Dead_Man%27s_Chest "Pirates of the
Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest")_ (2006) and _[At World's
End](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_At_World%27s_End "Pirates of the
Caribbean: At World's End")_, and considered it a good starting point for a
new movie in the series. Pre-production started after the end of the
[2007–2008 Writers Guild of America
strike](/wiki/2007%E2%80%932008_Writers_Guild_of_America_strike "2007–2008
Writers Guild of America strike"), with Depp collaborating with the writers on
the story design. [Principal photography](/wiki/Principal_photography
"Principal photography") rolled for 106 days between June and November 2010,
with locations in Hawaii, the United Kingdom, Puerto Rico and California.
Filming employed [3D](/wiki/3D_film "3D film") cameras similar to those used
in the production of the 2009 film _[Avatar](/wiki/Avatar_\(2009_film\)
"Avatar \(2009 film\)")_ , and ten companies were involved with the film's
[visual effects](/wiki/Visual_effects "Visual effects"). Following inflated
production costs it is currently noted as the [most expensive film ever
made](/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_films "List of most expensive films") with
a net budget of $379 million.

_On Stranger Tides_ broke many box office records upon release, and it stands
as the [23rd-highest-grossing film of all time
worldwide](/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films "List of highest-grossing
films") when not adjusting for inflation. Critical reviews were mixed, with
the film receiving criticism over its writing, directing, excessiveness and
lack of originality; positive mentions were given on the acting, action
sequences, music, visuals and the running time for being much shorter than the
previous two films. A sequel, titled _[Dead Men Tell No
Tales](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_Dead_Men_Tell_No_Tales "Pirates of the
Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales")_ , was released in 2017.

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

_This film 's story occurs in 1750, set roughly sixteen years after At World's
End (and six after its [post-credits scene](/wiki/Post-credits_scene "Post-
credits scene"))_

After a failed attempt to rescue his first mate, [Joshamee
Gibbs](/wiki/Joshamee_Gibbs "Joshamee Gibbs"), in London, [Captain Jack
Sparrow](/wiki/Jack_Sparrow "Jack Sparrow") is brought before [King George
II](/wiki/George_II_of_Great_Britain "George II of Great Britain"). The king
wants Jack to guide an expedition to the [Fountain of
Youth](/wiki/Fountain_of_Youth "Fountain of Youth") before [King
Ferdinand](/wiki/Ferdinand_VI_of_Spain "Ferdinand VI of Spain") and the
[Spanish Navy](/wiki/Spanish_Navy "Spanish Navy") can locate it. Jack's old
nemesis, Captain [Hector Barbossa](/wiki/Hector_Barbossa "Hector Barbossa"),
now a [privateer](/wiki/Privateer "Privateer") in service to the [British
Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy") after losing his leg and ship, the
_[Black Pearl](/wiki/Black_Pearl "Black Pearl")_ , which he says was sunk, is
heading the expedition.

Jack refuses the offer and escapes. He meets up with his father, [Captain
Teague](/wiki/Captain_Teague "Captain Teague"), who warns Jack about the
Fountain's rituals. Jack learns someone is impersonating him to recruit a crew
to find the Fountain. The impostor is
[Angelica](/wiki/Angelica_\(Pirates_of_the_Caribbean\) "Angelica \(Pirates of
the Caribbean\)"), Jack's former lover, and the daughter of the ruthless
pirate [Blackbeard](/wiki/Blackbeard_\(Pirates_of_the_Caribbean\) "Blackbeard
\(Pirates of the Caribbean\)"), who practices [voodoo](/wiki/Haitian_Vodou
"Haitian Vodou") magic and wields the mythical "Sword of
[Triton](/wiki/Triton_\(mythology\) "Triton \(mythology\)")" that controls his
ship, the _[Queen Anne's Revenge](/wiki/Queen_Anne%27s_Revenge "Queen Anne's
Revenge")_. While Jack is [shanghaied](/wiki/Shanghaiing "Shanghaiing") aboard
Blackbeard's ship, Gibbs escapes execution by memorizing and destroying Jack's
map showing the Fountain's location, forcing Barbossa to take him along.

Meanwhile, after a failed [mutiny](/wiki/Mutiny "Mutiny") aboard the _Queen
Anne 's Revenge_, Jack is forced to guide the crew to the Fountain. Blackbeard
seeks the Fountain's power to circumvent his predestined fatal encounter with
a "one-legged man", who happened to be Barbossa. Jack must find two silver
chalices aboard [Juan Ponce de León](/wiki/Juan_Ponce_de_Le%C3%B3n "Juan Ponce
de León")'s missing flagship, the _Santiago_. The Fountain's water must
simultaneously be drunk by two people from the chalices. Drinking from one
chalice containing a [mermaid](/wiki/Mermaid "Mermaid")'s tear will extend
life; the second person dies, their remaining years of life transferred to the
other drinker. Jack also discovers that the _Black Pearl_ was captured and
shrunk before being added to Blackbeard's collection of other shrunken [ships
in bottles](/wiki/Ship_in_a_bottle "Ship in a bottle").

The _Queen Anne 's Revenge_ heads for Whitecap Bay to find and harvest mermaid
tears. After managing to lure in a mermaid named Tamara, she summons other
mermaids to attack the crew before Jack causes an explosion that scares them
away. A mermaid named Syrena is caught, but Philip Swift, a captive
missionary, falls in love with her. Reaching Ponce de León's ship on an
uncharted island, Angelica and Blackbeard coerce Jack into retrieving both
chalices. Jack locates the grounded, decaying vessel, only to find Barbossa
there. Both guess that the Spanish have taken the chalices, after they are
nowhere to be found on the vessel.

Jack and Barbossa team up to sneak into the Spanish camp and steal the
chalices. Barbossa reveals he only wants revenge against Blackbeard for
attacking the _Black Pearl_ , and his leg being amputated. Jack and Barbossa
escape with the chalices. Meanwhile, Syrena, reciprocating Philip's love, is
tricked into shedding a tear. Blackbeard collects it, leaving her to die of
dehydration while Philip is forced to go with them. Jack returns with the
chalices and bargains with Blackbeard for Angelica's safety, Jack's
confiscated magical compass (which they took from him before sending him to
get the chalices), and Gibbs' release. In return, Jack vows to give Blackbeard
the chalices and lead him to the Fountain; Blackbeard agrees, and Gibbs is set
free with the compass.

At the Fountain, Blackbeard's crew is confronted by Barbossa and his men and
they battle while Barbossa and Blackbeard fight. The Spanish suddenly arrive,
intending to destroy the Fountain, believing its power an abomination against
God. They crush the chalices and throw them in the swamp. When Barbossa stabs
Blackbeard with a poisoned sword, Angelica pulls it out but is cut and
poisoned. Jack notices Angelica is poisoned and begins frantically searching
the swamp for the chalices. Barbossa obtains Blackbeard's magic sword and
gains control of the _Queen Anne 's Revenge_ and her crew. Despite resistance
from Blackbeard's crew, the Spanish successfully pull down a pillar, crushing
the Fountain of Youth. The Spanish army leaves once the fountain is in ruins.
Philip is mortally wounded, but he returns to free Syrena. She helps Jack
retrieve the missing chalices and gives them to him, telling him not to waste
her tear. Syrena goes back to the dying Philip. She says she can save him if
he asks her to. When he asks for her forgiveness, she kisses him and takes him
underwater.

With Blackbeard and Angelica both nearing death, Jack retrieves the last
remaining drops of water from the destroyed fountain and puts the tear in one
of them. Knowing that one of them must be sacrificed, he wants Angelica to
drink from the chalice containing the tear. Instead, Blackbeard drinks it,
asking his daughter to save him. Angelica agrees and drinks from the second
chalice. Jack is upset to lose Angelica, but reveals that he made a mistake
about which chalice contained the tear. Neither of the two are happy, and they
both believe Jack deliberately tricked them. Angelica's wounds are healed as
the Fountain fatally consumes Blackbeard's body.

Eventually, Jack and Angelica admit their love for each other, yet he
distrusts her intentions (aware that she may try to avenge her father) and
strands her on a [cay](/wiki/Cay "Cay"). Now wielding Blackbeard's magical
sword, Barbossa captains the _Queen Anne 's Revenge_ and returns to piracy.
Jack finds Gibbs, who had used the compass to locate the _Revenge_. He
reclaims the shrunken _Black Pearl_ and the other conquered ships in bottles,
carrying them in a [gunny sack](/wiki/Gunny_sack "Gunny sack"). The two leave,
hoping to revert the _Black Pearl_ to its original size and continue living
the pirates life.

In a [post-credits scene](/wiki/Post-credits_scene "Post-credits scene"), a
voodoo doll of Jack crafted by Blackbeard washes ashore and is found by
Angelica, who then smiles.

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

###
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Development")]

Shortly before the premiere of _[At World's
End](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_At_World%27s_End "Pirates of the
Caribbean: At World's End")_, [Jerry Bruckheimer](/wiki/Jerry_Bruckheimer
"Jerry Bruckheimer") stated it was the end of the trilogy, but the idea of a
spin-off was still possible.[4] After the film's successful opening weekend,
[Dick Cook](/wiki/Dick_Cook "Dick Cook"), then Chairman of the [Walt Disney
Studios](/wiki/List_of_assets_owned_by_Disney#Studio_Entertainment "List of
assets owned by Disney"), said he was interested in a fourth installment.
_[Los Angeles Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los Angeles Times")_ also
reported that rights to a book were bought.[5] [Ted
Elliott](/wiki/Ted_Elliott_\(screenwriter\) "Ted Elliott \(screenwriter\)")
and [Terry Rossio](/wiki/Terry_Rossio "Terry Rossio") had started working on a
script in 2007, but they were interrupted by the [2007–2008 Writers Guild of
America strike](/wiki/2007%E2%80%932008_Writers_Guild_of_America_strike
"2007–2008 Writers Guild of America strike"), and only resumed in mid-2008.[6]

In June 2009, Bruckheimer indicated Disney would prefer the fourth installment
of _Pirates_ to be released before _[The Lone
Ranger](/wiki/The_Lone_Ranger_\(2013_film\) "The Lone Ranger \(2013 film\)")_
film, which he, Johnny Depp, [Ted Elliott](/wiki/Ted_Elliott_\(screenwriter\)
"Ted Elliott \(screenwriter\)"), and [Terry Rossio](/wiki/Terry_Rossio "Terry
Rossio") had been working on for release on May 20, 2011. He hoped [Gore
Verbinski](/wiki/Gore_Verbinski "Gore Verbinski") would return to direct the
fourth film, as his _[BioShock](/wiki/BioShock#Canceled_film "BioShock")_ film
adaptation had been put on hold.[7] As Verbinski was unavailable due to his
commitment with _[Rango](/wiki/Rango_\(2011_film\) "Rango \(2011 film\)")_ the
same year, Bruckheimer suggested [Rob Marshall](/wiki/Rob_Marshall "Rob
Marshall"), who he considered a "premiere filmmaker", stating that "Every film
[Marshall] made I thought was unique and different."[8] On July 21, 2009,
Marshall accepted the job, because of the "whole new story line and set of
characters. It felt new, and that was important to me."[6] Marshall said the
film provided him a long-awaited opportunity to work with Depp, and that his
directing was helped by his experience as a choreographer—"the action
sequences felt like big production numbers."[9] On September 11, 2009, at
Disney's [D23](/wiki/D23_\(Disney\) "D23 \(Disney\)") convention during a
Disney event, Cook and Johnny Depp, in full Captain Jack Sparrow costume,
announced that a fourth _Pirates_ film was in development. The title was
announced as _Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides_.[10] Marshall
visited the [Pirates of the Caribbean
ride](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean_\(attraction\) "Pirates of the Caribbean
\(attraction\)") in Disneyland for inspiration, eventually paying homage with
a skeleton holding a magnifying glass in Ponce de León's ship. An appearance
of "Old Bill", the pirate who tries to share his rum with a cat, was also
filmed but cut.[11] [Pintel and Ragetti](/wiki/Pintel_and_Ragetti "Pintel and
Ragetti") were originally supposed to make an appearance, but director Rob
Marshall opted out of the idea as he feared their roles would be cut.[12]

Cook resigned in September 2009 after working for Disney for over 38
years.[13] Depp's faith in _Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides_ was
somewhat shaken after the resignation, with Depp explaining that "There's a
fissure, a crack in my enthusiasm at the moment. It was all born in that
office".[14] Depp also explained Cook was one of the few who accepted his
portrayal of Jack Sparrow: "When things went a little sideways on the [first
_Pirates_ movie](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_The_Curse_of_the_Black_Pearl
"Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl") and others at the
studio were less than enthusiastic about my interpretation of the character,
Dick was there from the first moment. He trusted me".[14]

###
Writing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Writing")]

During production of _[Dead Man's
Chest](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_Dead_Man%27s_Chest "Pirates of the
Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest")_ and _At World 's End_, writers [Ted
Elliott](/wiki/Ted_Elliott_\(screenwriter\) "Ted Elliott \(screenwriter\)")
and [Terry Rossio](/wiki/Terry_Rossio "Terry Rossio") discovered [Tim
Powers](/wiki/Tim_Powers "Tim Powers")' 1987 novel _[On Stranger
Tides](/wiki/On_Stranger_Tides "On Stranger Tides")_ , which they considered a
good foundation on which to base "a new chapter" in the _Pirates_ series.[8]
Disney bought the rights to the novel in April 2007.[15] Rossio stated that he
and Elliot had considered using Blackbeard and the Fountain of Youth in the
story before reading the book, "but whenever you say those words, Powers'
novel comes to mind. There was no way we could work in that field without
going into territory Tim had explored." However, they denied that it would be
a straight version of the novel: "Blackbeard came from the book, and in the
book there is a daughter character, too. But Jack Sparrow is not in the book,
nor is Barbossa. So I wouldn't call this an adaptation."[6] Rossio declared
the script was written to be a standalone film, "kind of a _[James
Bond](/wiki/James_Bond_in_film "James Bond in film")_ sort of thing", instead
of the "designed to be a trilogy" structure of the previous installments.[16]
They hoped to "design a story that would support new characters," as
characters such as [Will Turner](/wiki/Will_Turner "Will Turner") would not
return.[17] Bruckheimer added that there was a decision to "streamline the
story a little bit, make it a little simpler and not have as many characters
to follow", as the number of characters and subplots in _At World 's End_
caused the film to have an unwieldy length.[8] The duo decided to employ
another sea myth alluded in the previous episodes: mermaids,[16] which are
briefly referenced in the book. The mermaids' role expanded in the script,
which included a vast attack sequence.[17]

Depp was deeply involved with the story design, frequently meeting the writers
to show what he was interested in doing, and in the words of Rossio, being
"involved in coming up with story lines, connecting characters, creating
moments that we would then fashion, shape and then go back."[16] Among Depp's
suggestions were turning Phillip into a missionary and having a Spanish
contingent following the protagonists. Afterwards, Rob Marshall and executive
producer John DeLuca met Rossio and Elliot, and did alterations of their own,
including building the female lead.[17]

###
Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Casting")]

[![Johnny Depp in a film
premiere.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Johnny_Depp_2%2C_2011.jpg/175px-
Johnny_Depp_2%2C_2011.jpg)](/wiki/File:Johnny_Depp_2,_2011.jpg)

[![Geoffrey Rush in a
festival.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/GeoffreyRushTIFFSept2011.jpg/175px-
GeoffreyRushTIFFSept2011.jpg)](/wiki/File:GeoffreyRushTIFFSept2011.jpg)

[![Kevin
McNally.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Kevin_McNally.jpg/175px-
Kevin_McNally.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kevin_McNally.jpg)

Top to bottom: [Johnny Depp](/wiki/Johnny_Depp "Johnny Depp"), [Geoffrey
Rush](/wiki/Geoffrey_Rush "Geoffrey Rush"), and [Kevin
McNally](/wiki/Kevin_McNally "Kevin McNally") who reprised their roles from
the previous films as Captain Jack Sparrow, Captain Hector Barbossa, and
Joshamee Gibbs respectively.

Depp signed on to return as Captain Jack Sparrow in September 2008, saying
that he would come back if the script was good.[18] Almost a year later,
Disney announced that Depp would be paid $55.5 million for his role, realizing
that without him the franchise would be "dead and buried."[19] [Geoffrey
Rush](/wiki/Geoffrey_Rush "Geoffrey Rush") expressed interest in returning to
his role as Barbossa,[20] and Bruckheimer later confirmed his presence.[21]
Rush was positive on Barbossa having lost a leg, as he considered the
disability made him "angrier, more forceful and resilient as a character", and
had to work with the stunt team for an accurate portrayal of the limp and
usage of crutch, particularly during sword fighting scenes.[22] While the
production team considered a prop [pegleg](/wiki/Pegleg "Pegleg") to be put
over Rush's leg, the tight schedule caused it to be replaced with a [blue sock
that was replaced digitally](/wiki/Chroma_key "Chroma key"), with a knob on
the shoe to give Rush a reference for his walk.[23] Three other actors from
the previous films returned, [Kevin McNally](/wiki/Kevin_McNally "Kevin
McNally") as [Joshamee Gibbs](/wiki/Joshamee_Gibbs "Joshamee Gibbs"), [Greg
Ellis](/wiki/Greg_Ellis_\(actor\) "Greg Ellis \(actor\)") as Lt. Theodore
Groves,[24] and [Damian O'Hare](/wiki/Damian_O%27Hare "Damian O'Hare") as Lt.
Gilette.[25] [Keith Richards](/wiki/Keith_Richards "Keith Richards") also had
a cameo, reprising his role as [Captain Teague](/wiki/Captain_Teague "Captain
Teague") from _At World 's End_; he and Depp tried to persuade [Mick
Jagger](/wiki/Mick_Jagger "Mick Jagger") to audition for the part of a pirate
elder.[26] Previous cast members [Orlando Bloom](/wiki/Orlando_Bloom "Orlando
Bloom") and [Keira Knightley](/wiki/Keira_Knightley "Keira Knightley") stated
that they would not reprise their roles, as they wanted to be involved in
different films. They both thought the storyline involving their characters
had gone as far as it could.[27][28][29] On August 1, 2009, [Bill
Nighy](/wiki/Bill_Nighy "Bill Nighy") expressed his desire to return as Davy
Jones, who died in the [previous
film,](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_At_World%27s_End "Pirates of the
Caribbean: At World's End") saying the possibility to resurrect the character,
but at the end, his inclusion was scrapped.[30][31] On February 5, 2010,
[Mackenzie Crook](/wiki/Mackenzie_Crook "Mackenzie Crook") also announced he
would not be reprising his role of [Ragetti](/wiki/Pintel_and_Ragetti "Pintel
and Ragetti"), stating, "They haven't asked me. But actually I don't mind that
at all. I'm a fan of the first one especially and I think the trilogy we've
made is great. I'd almost like them to leave it there."[32]

New cast members include [Ian McShane](/wiki/Ian_McShane "Ian McShane"), who
plays the notorious pirate and primary antagonist of the film,
[Blackbeard](/wiki/Blackbeard "Blackbeard"), and [Penélope
Cruz](/wiki/Pen%C3%A9lope_Cruz "Penélope Cruz"), who plays Angelica, Jack
Sparrow's love interest.[21] According to Marshall, McShane was chosen because
"he can play something evil but there's always humor behind it as well" and
the actor accepted the job due to both the "very funny and charming" script
and the opportunity to work with Marshall.[33] The beard took one hour and a
half to get applied, and McShane likened the character's costume to "a real
[biker](/wiki/Outlaw_motorcycle_club "Outlaw motorcycle club") pirate—it's all
black leather.”[34] Marshall said Cruz was the only actress considered for the
role, as she fit the description as "an actress who could not only go toe to
toe with Johnny and match him, but also needed to be all the things that Jack
Sparrow is in a way. She needed to be funny and clever and smart and crafty
and beautiful",[9] and invited her for the role as they wrapped the production
of _[Nine](/wiki/Nine_\(2009_live-action_film\) "Nine \(2009 live-action
film\)")_.[23] The actress spent two months working out and learning fencing
for the role.[35] During filming, Cruz discovered she was pregnant, leading
the costume department to redesign her wardrobe to be more elastic,[23] and
the producers to hire her sister [Mónica Cruz](/wiki/M%C3%B3nica_Cruz "Mónica
Cruz") to double for Penélope in risky scenes.[36] Depp recommended [Stephen
Graham](/wiki/Stephen_Graham_\(actor\) "Stephen Graham \(actor\)"), who worked
with him in _[Public Enemies](/wiki/Public_Enemies_\(2009_film\) "Public
Enemies \(2009 film\)")_ , to play Scrum, a Machiavellian pirate and sidekick
to Jack Sparrow,[37][38] and [Richard Griffiths](/wiki/Richard_Griffiths
"Richard Griffiths") for the role of [King George
II](/wiki/George_II_of_Great_Britain "George II of Great Britain"), as Depp
was a fan of Griffiths' work on _[Withnail and I](/wiki/Withnail_and_I
"Withnail and I")_.[23] [Sam Claflin](/wiki/Sam_Claflin "Sam Claflin"), a
recent drama school graduate with television experience, was chosen to play
the missionary Philip,[39] and British actor [Paul Bazely](/wiki/Paul_Bazely
"Paul Bazely") also joined the cast.[40] Spanish news website _[El
Pais](/wiki/El_Pais "El Pais")_ reported that the film had four Spanish
actors: Cruz, Bergès-Frisbey, Óscar Jaenada, and [Juan Carlos
Vellido](/wiki/Juan_Carlos_Vellido "Juan Carlos Vellido").[41] Jaenada was
picked for both his work in _[The Losers](/wiki/The_Losers_\(film\) "The
Losers \(film\)")_ and a recommendation by Cruz.[42]

Casting for mermaids required the actresses to have natural breasts—no
[implants](/wiki/Breast_implant "Breast implant"). As Bruckheimer explained to
_[EW](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly "Entertainment Weekly")_ , "I don't think
they had breast augmentation in the 1700s, [...] So it's natural for casting
people to say, 'We want real people.'"[43] Marshall invited Spanish-French
actress [Àstrid Bergès-Frisbey](/wiki/%C3%80strid_Berg%C3%A8s-Frisbey "Àstrid
Bergès-Frisbey") to play Syrena after seeing her in a French magazine article
on up-and-coming actresses.[22] Bergès-Frisbey had to take lessons of English,
swimming and breath control for the role.[44] The rest of the mermaid
portrayers, such as Australian supermodel [Gemma Ward](/wiki/Gemma_Ward "Gemma
Ward"),[45] were chosen for having "exotic sense, an otherworldly sensibility,
but also under those layers a deadly quality", according to Marshall, and had
to take swimming lessons to learn movements such as the
[dolphin](/wiki/Butterfly_stroke "Butterfly stroke") and [eggbeater
kicks](/wiki/Eggbeater_kick "Eggbeater kick").[46]

###
Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Filming")]

[Principal photography](/wiki/Principal_photography "Principal photography")
began on June 14, 2010, in Hawaii.[17][47] Filming was moved to California in
August 2010,[48] primarily at the [Long Beach](/wiki/Long_Beach,_California
"Long Beach, California") shore[33] and a recreation of Whitecap Bay done in
the [Universal Studios](/wiki/Universal_Studios "Universal Studios")
backlot,[17] as the original Hawaiian location on [Halona
Cove](/wiki/Halona_Blowhole#Halona_Cove "Halona Blowhole") was plagued with
strong tides.[22] After a brief shoot in [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico
"Puerto Rico"),[33] with locations in both [Palomino
Island](/wiki/Isla_Palominos_\(Puerto_Rico\) "Isla Palominos \(Puerto Rico\)")
and the [Fort of San
Cristóbal](/wiki/Castillo_de_San_Crist%C3%B3bal_\(Puerto_Rico\) "Castillo de
San Cristóbal \(Puerto Rico\)") in [San Juan](/wiki/San_Juan,_Puerto_Rico "San
Juan, Puerto Rico"),[49] production moved to the United Kingdom in September,
where principal photography wrapped on November 18 after 106 days of
shooting.[17] Locations included [Hampton Court
Palace](/wiki/Hampton_Court_Palace "Hampton Court Palace") in London,[23]
[Knole House](/wiki/Knole_House "Knole House") in [Kent](/wiki/Kent
"Kent"),[33] and [Old Royal Naval College](/wiki/Old_Royal_Naval_College "Old
Royal Naval College") at [Greenwich](/wiki/Greenwich "Greenwich").[50]
Interiors were shot at London's [Pinewood Studios](/wiki/Pinewood_Studios
"Pinewood Studios"), and a replica of an 18th-century London street was built
on the backlot alongside the soundstages.[33][51] The producers also
considered using [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans") as a
location.[52] In October, security was breached at the UK site when a
[celebrity impersonator](/wiki/Celebrity_impersonator "Celebrity
impersonator") gained access to filming at the Old Royal Naval College by
dressing up as Captain Jack.[53]

After the joint production of _Dead Man 's Chest_ and _At World 's End_ cost
over $300 million, Disney decided to give a lower budget to the fourth
installment.[54] Many costs had to be cut, including moving primary production
to Hawaii and London, where tax credits are more favorable, and having a
shorter shooting schedule and fewer scenes featuring special effects compared
to _At World 's End_.[55] The tighter schedule—according to Bruckheimer, "We
had a 22-week post, and for a picture like this, with almost 1,200 visual
effects shots, it's usually 40 weeks"—meant that Marshall supervised editing
of sequences during filming.[17] The British financial statements of the film
revealed total expenditures of £240.7 million ($410.6 million) by 2013, with
Disney receiving a rebate of $32.1 million from the British government, making
_Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides_ the [most expensive film ever
made](/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_films "List of most expensive films") to
date.[2]

Bruckheimer said the decision to film in 3D was made due to its being
"immersive filmmaking; I think it makes you part of the actual filming because
you're part of the screen." Bruckheimer described it as the first major
"exterior movie" to be shot in 3D, as _[Avatar](/wiki/Avatar_\(2009_film\)
"Avatar \(2009 film\)")_ was mostly done in sound stages.[8] At first Marshall
was not much interested in 3D, but the director eventually considered it a
film that could benefit from the format. "You are on an adventure and with the
3D experience you are inside that adventure."[9] While the original plan was
to add 3D effects during post-production, the decision was made to shoot
digitally with 3D cameras. Only one sequence was shot conventionally and
needed a [3D conversion](/wiki/2D_to_3D_conversion "2D to 3D conversion").[8]
The cameras were improved versions of the ones [James
Cameron](/wiki/James_Cameron "James Cameron") developed for _Avatar_ , which
were made more compact for extra mobility. This meant the cameras could be
brought into locations such as the Hawaiian jungle.[56]

The _Queen Anne 's Revenge_ was built atop the _Sunset_ , the same ship used
to depict the _Black Pearl_ in previous installments. On February 2010, the
_Sunset_ was sailed from Long Beach to a shipyard in Hawaii for the reforms,
where a big concern was to make it imposing, with three stories, without
sacrificing actual [seakeeping](/wiki/Seakeeping "Seakeeping"). Given
Blackbeard was meant to be the meanest pirate to appear in the series, the
look for the _Queen Anne 's Revenge_ was ominous, with sails dyed blood red,
various elements on fire, and a decoration based on skulls and bones (drawing
inspiration from the [Sedlec Ossuary](/wiki/Sedlec_Ossuary "Sedlec Ossuary")
in Czech Republic). Damage from cannon fire was also added to show that "not
only Blackbeard was a dying man, but his ship is also a dying ship". The
ship's [figurehead](/wiki/Figurehead "Figurehead") also drew inspiration from
Blackbeard's [pirate flag](/wiki/Jolly_Roger "Jolly Roger").[57] The replica
ship [HMS _Surprise_](/wiki/HMS_Surprise_\(replica_ship\) "HMS Surprise
\(replica ship\)") was used for Barbossa's ship, the HMS _Providence_ ,[58]
and all the scenes aboard the _Providence_ were shot on the Long Beach shore
as the _Surprise_ could not be sailed to Hawaii.[23] Over 50 designs were
considered for the Fountain of Youth, with the final one representing a temple
built by an ancient civilization around the Fountain, which itself was located
in a round rocky structure to represent "the circle of life". The locations
leading up to the Fountain were shot in the Hawaiian islands of
[Kauai](/wiki/Kauai "Kauai") and [Oahu](/wiki/Oahu "Oahu"), but the Fountain
itself was built at the [007 Stage](/wiki/007_Stage "007 Stage") on
Pinewood.[59]

###
Effects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Effects")]

_On Stranger Tides_ employed 1,112 shots of [computer-generated
imagery](/wiki/Computer-generated_imagery "Computer-generated imagery"),[17]
which were done by ten visual effects companies.[60] [Cinesite](/wiki/Cinesite
"Cinesite") visual effects supervisor Simon Stanley-Clamp claimed that the
most difficult part was doing the effects in 3D:
"[Rotoscoping](/wiki/Rotoscoping "Rotoscoping") is tricky. Cleaning up plates
is double the work, and [tracking](/wiki/Match_moving "Match moving") has to
be spot on."[50] The lead companies, with over 300 effects each, were
[Industrial Light & Magic](/wiki/Industrial_Light_%26_Magic "Industrial Light
& Magic")—responsible for, among others, the mermaids and most water
effects[61]—and [Moving Picture Company](/wiki/Moving_Picture_Company "Moving
Picture Company"), who created digital ships and environment extensions, such
as changing weather and designing cliffs and waterfalls.[62] Filming the
mermaids involved eight model-actresses, who portrayed them outside the water,
as well as 22 [synchronized swimming](/wiki/Synchronized_swimming
"Synchronized swimming") athletes and a group of stuntwomen, both of whom wore
[motion capture](/wiki/Motion_capture "Motion capture") suits to be later
replaced by digital mermaids. Mermaid corpses were depicted by plaster
models.[33][46] The design tried to avoid the traditional representations of
mermaids in paintings and literature, instead going for a scaly body with a
translucent membrane inspired by both jellyfish and the fabric employed in
[ballet tutus](/wiki/Ballet_tutu "Ballet tutu"). To make the mermaids more
menacing underwater, the faces of the actresses had some digital touch-ups on
the underwater scenes, adding sharper teeth and a shimmery fish scale quality
on the skin.[63] ILM also handled Blackbeard's death, where Ian McShane's
actual performance was covered by digital doubles which turned him into a
"boiling mass of blood and clothing", and a hurricane-like formation that
represented "the waters of the Fountain taking his life".[59] Cinesite handled
the recreation of London and Barbossa's peg leg,[50] CIS Hollywood did 3D
corrections and minor shots, and [Method Studios](/wiki/Method_Studios "Method
Studios") created [matte paintings](/wiki/Matte_painting "Matte
painting").[64]

###
Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Music")]

Main article: [Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides
(soundtrack)](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides_\(soundtrack\)
"Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides \(soundtrack\)")

The [film's score](/wiki/Film_score "Film score") was written by [Hans
Zimmer](/wiki/Hans_Zimmer "Hans Zimmer"), who had worked in all of the
previous entries in the franchise; being the main composer for the second and
third installments.[65] Zimmer said that he tried to incorporate a rock n'
roll sound, as he felt "pirates were the rock 'n' rollers of many, many years
ago",[66] and Spanish elements, which led to a collaboration with Mexican
guitarists [Rodrigo y Gabriela](/wiki/Rodrigo_y_Gabriela "Rodrigo y Gabriela")
and a [tango](/wiki/Tango_music "Tango music") song written by Penélope Cruz's
brother Eduardo.[67] American composer [Eric Whitacre](/wiki/Eric_Whitacre
"Eric Whitacre") contributed several choir-based cues,[67][68] as well as
regular assistant [Geoff Zanelli](/wiki/Geoff_Zanelli "Geoff Zanelli").[65]

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Release")]

[![On a staircase with a red carpet stand both a man wearing glasses and a
white jacket atop a black business suit, and a woman wearing a blue dress with
transparencies.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Pen%C3%A9lope_Cruz_and_Johnny_Depp_-
_Cannes_2011.jpg/170px-Pen%C3%A9lope_Cruz_and_Johnny_Depp_-
_Cannes_2011.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pen%C3%A9lope_Cruz_and_Johnny_Depp_-
_Cannes_2011.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Pen%C3%A9lope_Cruz_and_Johnny_Depp_-_Cannes_2011.jpg "Enlarge")

[Penélope Cruz](/wiki/Pen%C3%A9lope_Cruz "Penélope Cruz") and [Johnny
Depp](/wiki/Johnny_Depp "Johnny Depp") promoting the film at the [2011 Cannes
Film Festival](/wiki/2011_Cannes_Film_Festival "2011 Cannes Film Festival").

On January 6, 2010, Disney announced that the film would be released in the
United States and Canada on May 20, 2011, following [Columbia
Pictures](/wiki/Columbia_Pictures "Columbia Pictures")' announcement of a
delay in the [_Spider-Man_ reboot](/wiki/The_Amazing_Spider-Man_\(2012_film\)
"The Amazing Spider-Man \(2012 film\)") and [Paramount
Pictures](/wiki/Paramount_Pictures "Paramount Pictures") slating
_[Thor](/wiki/Thor_\(film\) "Thor \(film\)")_ for May 6, 2011.[69] The film
was released in [IMAX 3D](/wiki/IMAX_3D "IMAX 3D"), as well as traditional 2D
and [IMAX](/wiki/IMAX "IMAX") format,[70][71] with Dolby [7.1 surround
sound](/wiki/7.1_surround_sound "7.1 surround sound").[72] This film was also
the first film to be released in the [4DX](/wiki/4DX "4DX") motion theaters in
[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico") and in the [Western
Hemisphere](/wiki/Western_Hemisphere "Western Hemisphere"), featuring strobe
lights, tilting seats, blowing wind and fog and odor effects.[73] It is
available exclusively at select [Cinépolis](/wiki/Cin%C3%A9polis "Cinépolis")
cinemas.[74]

The [world premiere](/wiki/Premiere "Premiere") of _On Stranger Tides_ was on
May 7, 2011, at a premium ticket screening at [Disneyland](/wiki/Disneyland
"Disneyland") in [Anaheim, California](/wiki/Anaheim,_California "Anaheim,
California"), home of the original _[Pirates of the
Caribbean](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean_\(attraction\) "Pirates of the
Caribbean \(attraction\)")_ ride that inspired the film series. Many of the
film's stars were in attendance. Two other early screenings followed, one in
Moscow on May 11,[75] and another during the [Cannes International Film
Festival](/wiki/Cannes_International_Film_Festival "Cannes International Film
Festival") on May 14.[76] The international release dates fell within May 18
and 20, with opening dates in the United Kingdom on May 18, in Australia on
May 19, and in North America on May 20.[77][78][79][80] The film was released
on a then-record 402 IMAX screens, 257 screens in North America, and 139 in
other territories.[81] The total number of theaters was 4,155 in North America
and 18,210 worldwide.[82][83]

###
Promotion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Promotion")]

Disney's marketing president, [MT Carney](/wiki/MT_Carney "MT Carney"), said
that the film's advertising campaign was intended "to remind people of why
they fell in love with Jack Sparrow in the first place and also introduce new
elements in a way that was elegant".[17] [Sony Pictures](/wiki/Sony_Pictures
"Sony Pictures")' former marketing president, Valerie Van Galder, was hired as
a consultant.[84] The first footage from the film appeared on _[Entertainment
Tonight](/wiki/Entertainment_Tonight "Entertainment Tonight")_ on December 4,
2010.[85] Three trailers were released,[17] one in December, which had a 3D
version included with the release of _[Tron: Legacy](/wiki/Tron:_Legacy "Tron:
Legacy")_[71] and broadcast by [ESPN 3D](/wiki/ESPN_3D "ESPN 3D");[86] a
[Super Bowl XLV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLV "Super Bowl XLV")
[spot](/wiki/Super_Bowl_advertising "Super Bowl advertising") on February
2011, which was later released online in an extended version;[87] and a final
trailer in March that focused more on the plot than the previous trailer and
commercials.[88]

Promotional tie-ins included _[Lego Pirates of the
Caribbean](/wiki/Lego_Pirates_of_the_Caribbean "Lego Pirates of the
Caribbean")_ toy sets and [a related video
game](/wiki/Lego_Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_The_Video_Game "Lego Pirates of the
Caribbean: The Video Game"),[89][90] a cell phone app by [Verizon
Wireless](/wiki/Verizon_Wireless "Verizon Wireless"),[91] a special edition of
[Pirate's Booty](/wiki/Pirate%27s_Booty "Pirate's Booty"),[92] lines of nail
polish by OPI,[93] clothing from [Hot Topic](/wiki/Hot_Topic "Hot Topic"),[94]
and jewelry from [Swarovski](/wiki/Swarovski "Swarovski").[95] [Goldline
International](/wiki/Goldline_International "Goldline International") produced
replicas of the "[Pieces of Eight](/wiki/Spanish_dollar "Spanish dollar")"
coins from the movies and [gold Mexican Escudo](/wiki/Spanish_escudo "Spanish
escudo") coins, which were given in sweepstakes at the [El Capitan
Theatre](/wiki/El_Capitan_Theatre "El Capitan Theatre").[96] At [Disney
California Adventure Park](/wiki/Disney_California_Adventure_Park "Disney
California Adventure Park"), the _Pirates of the Caribbean_ segment of the
_[World of Color](/wiki/World_of_Color "World of Color")_ show was extended to
include visual clips and music from _On Stranger Tides_.[97]

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Home media")]

The film was released on DVD and Blu-Ray on September 12, 2011 in the UK,
topping both the Blu-ray and DVD sales charts during its first two weeks. The
film had its high-definition home release on October 18, 2011 in the United
States and Canada. Three different physical packages were made available: a
2-disc combo pack (Blu-ray and DVD), a 5-disc combo pack (2-disc Blu-ray,
1-disc Blu-ray 3D, 1-disc DVD, and 1-disc Digital Copy), and a 15-disc
collection featuring all four _Pirates_ movies. _On Stranger Tides_ was also
released as a movie download in both high definition and 3D.[98][99][100] The
regular DVD edition came out on December 6.[101]

In its first week of release, it sold 1.71 million Blu-ray units and generated
$48.50 million, topping the weekly Blu-ray chart. However these results were
quite skewed due to the one-month delay of its DVD-only release.[102] It sold
3.20 million Blu-ray units ($83.46 million) after 11 weeks.[103] It has also
sold 1.12 million DVD units ($19.32 million).[104] Upon its television
premiere on December 29, 2013 in the UK on [BBC One](/wiki/BBC_One "BBC One"),
it was watched by a total of 5.4 million viewers, making it the third-most
watched program that night, according to overnight figures.[105]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Box office")]

_On Stranger Tides_ earned $241,071,802 in the North America and $804,642,000
in other countries for a worldwide total of $1,045,713,802.[106] It is the
[22nd highest-grossing film worldwide](/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films
"List of highest-grossing films"), the [third-highest-grossing 2011
film](/wiki/2011_in_film "2011 in film"), the second-most successful
installment of the [_Pirates of the Caribbean_
series](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean_\(film_series\) "Pirates of the
Caribbean \(film series\)"), the eleventh-highest-grossing
[Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures "Walt Disney Pictures") feature and the
second-highest-grossing fourth film in a franchise (behind Transformers: Age
of Extinction).[107] On its worldwide opening weekend, it grossed $350.6
million, surpassing _At World 's End_'s $344 million opening as best in the
series and ranking as the seventh-highest worldwide opening.[108] It scored an
[IMAX](/wiki/IMAX "IMAX") worldwide opening-weekend record with $16.7
million[109] (first surpassed by _[Transformers: Dark of the
Moon](/wiki/Transformers:_Dark_of_the_Moon "Transformers: Dark of the
Moon")_).[110]

It set records for the least time to reach $500, $600, and $700 million
worldwide (in 10, 12 and 16 days, respectively).[111][112][113] The first of
these records was first surpassed by _Dark of the Moon_[114] and the other two
by _[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part
2](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows_%E2%80%93_Part_2 "Harry Potter
and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2")_.[115] After 46 days in theaters (July 2,
2011), it became the eighth film in cinema history and the fourth film
released by Walt Disney Studios to cross the $1-billion-mark.[116] It set a
record for the fastest Disney-distributed film to reach the milestone (first
surpassed by _[Marvel's The Avengers](/wiki/The_Avengers_\(2012_film\) "The
Avengers \(2012 film\)")_)[117] and it is the fifth-fastest film overall to
achieve this.[118]

#### North
America[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: North America")]

During its Thursday-midnight showings, _On Stranger Tides_ earned $4.7 million
from 2,210 theaters,[119] and $34,860,549 in total on its opening day.[120] It
earned $90,151,958 on its opening weekend, topping the weekend box office, but
earning much less than its two immediate predecessors (_At World 's End_ –
$114.7 million and _Dead Man 's Chest_ – $135.6 million) and the directly
preceding [Johnny Depp](/wiki/Johnny_Depp "Johnny Depp") spectacle (_[Alice in
Wonderland](/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland_\(2010_film\) "Alice in Wonderland
\(2010 film\)")_ – $116.1 million).[121] 3D showings accounted for only 46% of
its opening-weekend gross.[122] It closed on September 29, 2011, with a $241.1
million gross, ranking as the fifth-highest-grossing film of 2011[123] and the
least profitable film of the franchise.[124] However, it was the top-grossing
movie during May 2011 (with $166.8 million by May 31).[125]

#### Outside North
America[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Outside North America")]

Outside North America, _On Stranger Tides_ is the sixth-highest-grossing
film,[126] the third-highest-grossing Disney film,[127] the second-highest-
grossing 2011 film and the highest-grossing film of the _Pirates of the
Caribbean_ series.[128] It is the highest-grossing _Pirates_ film in at least
58 territories.[116]

During its opening day (Wednesday, May 18, 2011), _On Stranger Tides_ made
$18.5 million from 10 territories.[129] It added 37 territories and $25.7
million on Thursday, for a two-day total of $44.2 million,[130] and on Friday,
it expanded to almost all countries, earning $46.2 million for a three-day
total of $92.1 million.[131] On its five-day opening weekend as a whole, it
earned a then-record $260.4 million from 18,210 screens in more than 100
territories, in all which it reached first place at the box office.[132] The
record debut was surpassed later in the same summer season by _Deathly Hallows
Part 2_.[133] Earnings originating from 3-D showings accounted for 66% of the
weekend gross, which was a much greater share than in North America.[122] Its
highest-grossing countries during its first weekend were Russia and the CIS
($31.42 million including previews),[134] China ($22.3 million)[135] and
Germany ($20.53 million).[136][137] It dominated for three weekends at the
overseas box office despite competition from _[The Hangover Part
II](/wiki/The_Hangover_Part_II "The Hangover Part II")_ , _[Kung Fu Panda
2](/wiki/Kung_Fu_Panda_2 "Kung Fu Panda 2")_ , and _[X-Men: First
Class](/wiki/X-Men:_First_Class "X-Men: First Class")_.[138][139] It reached
the $300, $400 and $500-million-mark at the box office outside North America
in record time (7, 11 and 14 days respectively), records first surpassed by
_Deathly Hallows – Part 2_.[116][140][141]

_On Stranger Tides_ set opening day records in both Russia (including the CIS)
and Sweden.[129] Subsequently, it set opening-weekend records in Latin
America, the Middle East, Russia, Norway, Ukraine and Turkey,[83] still
retaining the record in Russia ($26.8 million)[142] and Ukraine ($2.15
million).[143] Its highest-grossing market after North America is Japan
($108.9 million), followed by China ($71.8 million)[144] and Russia and the
CIS ($63.7 million).[145] It is the highest-grossing film of 2011 in Russia
and the CIS,[146] Austria,[147] Ukraine,[148] Greece,[149] Portugal and
Angola,[150] South Africa,[151] Romania,[152] Bulgaria,[153] Egypt,[154]
Estonia,[155] and Latvia.[145][156]

### Critical
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Critical reception")]

Review aggregation website [Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten
Tomatoes") gives the film an approval rating of 33% based on 259 reviews, with
an average rating of 5/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "It's shorter
and leaner than the previous sequel, but this _Pirates_ runs aground on a
disjointed plot and a non-stop barrage of noisy action sequences."[157]
[Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"), which assigns a [weighted
average](/wiki/Weighted_average "Weighted average") rating to reviews, gives
the film an average score of 45 out of 100, based on 39 critics, indicating
"mixed or average reviews".[158] [CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore
"CinemaScore") polls reported that the average grade moviegoers gave the film
was a "B+" on an A+ to F scale.[82]

[Roger Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") gave _On Stranger Tides_ two
out of four stars, saying that although the removal of Knightley and Bloom as
well as the addition of Cruz were positive aspects, the film in general was
"too much of a muchness" for him.[159] Tom Long of _[The Detroit
News](/wiki/The_Detroit_News "The Detroit News")_ gave a D+, saying that Jack
Sparrow had "worn out his welcome". Despite the more linear plot, "the movie
is still ridiculous". He found _On Stranger Tides_ to be "precisely what you'd
expect of the fourth installment of a movie based on an amusement park ride: a
whole lot of noise, plenty of stunts and complete silliness."[160] British
film critic [Mark Kermode](/wiki/Mark_Kermode "Mark Kermode") gave the film an
overwhelmingly negative review on his _[5 Live](/wiki/5_Live "5 Live")_ show,
saying "it's not as staggeringly misjudged as the third part, because it is
just nothing, it is just a big empty nothing, whereas part three I think was
an active atrocity, it's just nothing at all".[161]

As with the previous films, the plot was criticized as incoherent and
confusing. _[The Arizona Republic](/wiki/The_Arizona_Republic "The Arizona
Republic")_ critic Bill Goodykoontz rated the film two out of five, stating
that "the movie is a series of distractions tossed together in the hopes that
they will come together in a coherent story. That never really happens."[162]
Online reviewer [James Berardinelli](/wiki/James_Berardinelli "James
Berardinelli") considered the script "little more than a clothesline from
which to dangle all of the obligatory set pieces",[163] and _[USA
Today](/wiki/USA_Today "USA Today")_ 's Claudia Puig found _On Stranger Tides_
"familiar and predictable...often incoherent and crammed with pointless
details."[164]

Mike Scott from _[The Times-Picayune](/wiki/The_Times-Picayune "The Times-
Picayune")_ mentions that "while this latest chapter isn't quite sharp enough
to restore the sense of discovery that made that first outing so darn
exciting, it's enough to make up for most of the missteps that made the third
one so darn arrgh-inducing."[165] Writing for _[The A.V.
Club](/wiki/The_A.V._Club "The A.V. Club")_ , Tasha Robinson described _On
Stranger Tides_ as "a smaller film than past installments, by design and
necessity", and felt that "the series has needed this streamlining" as the
film "feels lightweight, but that's still better than bloated."[166]

_On Stranger Tides_ also had positive reviews; some critics found the film to
be entertaining and well-made. [Richard Roeper](/wiki/Richard_Roeper "Richard
Roeper") gave the film a B+, describing it as "the most fun installment since
the first", calling the story "pure cartoon, but a lot easier to follow than
the other sequels", and summing as "the franchise is getting tired, but
Penelope energizes it."[167] Along the same lines, Ann Hornaday of _[The
Washington Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The Washington Post")_ gave the
film three out of four stars, writing that it "feels as fresh and bracingly
exhilarating as the day Jack Sparrow first swashed his buckle, infusing new
reckless energy into a franchise that shows no signs of furling its sails".
She said that Marshall "swiftly and without fuss delivers the action set
pieces and eye-popping escapism" and praised Depp, Cruz, and McShane's
performances.[168] Ray Bennett from _[The Hollywood
Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood Reporter")_ considered
that Marshall "shows terrific flair with all the usual chases and sword
fights, and he handles the 3D well", and welcomed Penélope Cruz's character,
saying she "brings her Oscar-winning vivacity" and had "lively sexual tension"
with Depp.[169] Writing for _[The Globe and Mail](/wiki/The_Globe_and_Mail
"The Globe and Mail")_ , Rick Groen found the action scenes to range from
"merely competent to tritely cluttered", but he was pleased with the overall
result, calling McShane a "fresh villain" whose "stentorian tones are welcome
anywhere".[170] _[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety
\(magazine\)")'s_ Andrew Barker considered the film derivative, but
accessible. "It has nary an original idea and still doesn't make much sense,
but it's lost all pretensions that it should". He praised Geoffrey Rush,
stating that he "not only gets the funniest lines and reaction shots, but also
starts to siphon away much of the roguish charm that used to be Depp's stock
and trade."[168]

###
Accolades[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Accolades")]

See also: [List of accolades received by the Pirates of the Caribbean
franchise](/wiki/List_of_accolades_received_by_the_Pirates_of_the_Caribbean_franchise
"List of accolades received by the Pirates of the Caribbean franchise")

The film was nominated for four [Teen Choice Awards](/wiki/Teen_Choice_Awards
"Teen Choice Awards"): Sci-Fi/Fantasy Movie, Sci-Fi/Fantasy Actor, Sci-
Fi/Fantasy Actress, and Villain.[171] Its trailer and TV spot were nominated
for [Golden Trailer Awards](/wiki/Golden_Trailer_Awards "Golden Trailer
Awards").[172] The film won Best Movie for Mature Audiences Award at the 2012
[Movieguide Awards](/wiki/Movieguide_Awards "Movieguide Awards").[173]

##
Sequel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_On_Stranger_Tides&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Sequel")]

Further information: [Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No
Tales](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_Dead_Men_Tell_No_Tales "Pirates of the
Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales")

On May 29, 2013, it was announced that _[Kon-Tiki](/wiki/Kon-
Tiki_\(2012_film\) "Kon-Tiki \(2012 film\)")_ directors [Joachim
Rønning](/wiki/Joachim_R%C3%B8nning "Joachim Rønning") and [Espen
Sandberg](/wiki/Espen_Sandberg "Espen Sandberg") would be directing _Pirates
of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales_.[174][175]

While earlier reports stated _Dead Men Tell No Tales_ would be released
between 2015 and 2016,[176] Disney announced in 2014 that the film would enter
theaters on July 2017.[177] Production began in late February 2015 in
Australia.[178]

qa.question: where was pirates of the carribean on stranger tides filmed
qa.answer: ["Principal photography began on June 14, 2010, in Hawaii.[17][47] Filming was moved to California in August 2010,[48] primarily at the Long Beach shore[33] and a recreation of Whitecap Bay done in the Universal Studios backlot,[17] as the original Hawaiian location on Halona Cove was plagued with strong tides.[22] After a brief shoot in Puerto Rico,[33] with locations in both Palomino Island and the Fort of San Cristóbal in San Juan,[49] production moved to the United Kingdom in September, where principal photography wrapped on November 18 after 106 days of shooting.[17] Locations included Hampton Court Palace in London,[23] Knole House in Kent,[33] and Old Royal Naval College at Greenwich.[50] Interiors were shot at London's Pinewood Studios, and a replica of an 18th-century London street was built on the backlot alongside the soundstages"]
